page.text: Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street
Glen Van Nimwegen, AICP, Director of Community Development
Should the city change the zoning of land with single-family, commercial or mixed-use zoning at 2100 W.
Littleton Boulevard and 5759 S. Bemis Street to residential zoning at the intensity proposed by the requested
On June 24, 2013, the Planning Board reviewed the proposed rezoning and general planned development plan
for 250 units and voted 7-0 to deny Planning Board Resolution No. 13-03, which recommended conditional
approval. On July 8, 2013, the Board voted 7-0 to approve Planning Board Resolution No. 13-04 that forwards
a recommendation of denial to City Council.
The public hearing for City Council was set for July 30 at which time the applicant proposed the following
• Reduced height from five stories to four;
• Reduced the number of units from 250 to 225 decreasing the density from 56 du/ac to 50 du/ac; and
• Increased the building setback on Littleton Boulevard from 10 to 15 feet.
Instead of proceeding with the scheduled public hearing, City Council voted 6-1 to remand the rezoning request
back to the Planning Board for review in light of the changes to the project proposed by the developer. In
addition, the applicant is proposing berming on the west side of the site. Constructing the berm in the city ditch
easement will require a license from the City of Englewood. Englewood city staff has expressed initial concern
The previous staff recommendation included twelve conditions, which were attached to the proposed ordinance.
The applicant has agreed to comply with all of the recommended conditions and has incorporated them into the
revised PD plan. Table 1: Changes made to PD Plan, was put together by staff to specifically indicate where the
conditions were incorporated into the PD document.
Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street
For this project area and request, two sets of policies must be evaluated:
• The Citywide Goals, Sterne Park and Downtown Neighborhood Plan portions of the COMPLAN; and
• The Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study and Design Guidelines for the Sheriff’s Department Site (2000

text.b: Following are the pertinent criteria from the above-referenced documents, which was used to evaluate the
proposal. The staff comments are denoted below each statement in italics

page.text: The proposal with the recommended conditions of approval is consistent with the following pertinent Community-
wide goals and policies of the COMPLAN:
Preserve Littleton’s unique identity by protecting historic structures and emphasizing Littleton’s
distinct social and economic heritage with consideration given to:
Encouragement of variety in housing stock and types of people.

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan: With the walkout basement level, the west side of the building will be six stories for the
majority of the elevation. However, the two separate buildings break up the visual massing along with additional
step backs and design requirements will create at least five sub-masses. The proposed maximum number of floors
and setbacks from Littleton Blvd. (5’ step back above the 2
nd
floor, 25’ step back above the 3
rd
floor and then 70’
back above the 4
th
floor) lower the building massing significantly reinforcing the prominence of the Historic
Courthouse. Staff condition #4 is review of the architectural, site and landscape design by the Planning Board
thereby ensuring that the massing and architectural details will respect the Historic Courthouse and result in an
aesthetically pleasing view from downtown.

i.b: NOW: The lower building height, the greater setback from Littleton Boulevard, the screening of the walkout
basement level with a berm and the additional step backs and design requirements now give an appearance of
several three and four-story buildings along the western edge. The additional setback from Littleton Boulevard
combined with the lower building height further reduces the scale of the northerly portion of the building in
relation to the Historic Courthouse. Staff’s recommended condition #4 as stated above has been added under
the Development Conditions on Sheet 2.

page.text: Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street
Goal 2: Develop Littleton’s economic independence and reemphasize downtown as Littleton’s economic and social

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
: Development of the site at the full potential of the existing B-2 zoning will have greater
impact on the adjoining neighborhoods, which is in conflict with other goals to protect the neighborhood. The
additional residences will increase the market for Main Street and Littleton Boulevard businesses and staff
condition #5 provides the opportunity for a limited residential use. The adopted design guidelines for this area
recommend multiple family residential in this location to support the nearby light rail transit station. Included
in the attached application materials, the applicant has provided a fiscal benefit comparison showing greater
annual revenues and one-time fee and taxes for the proposed residential development versus a mixed use
allowed under the present B-2 zoning.

i.b: NOW: The above statement still applies. Recommended staff condition #5 is noted under the Development
Conditions on Sheet 2 of the PD Plan.

page.text: Goal 7: Promote and maintain an attractive and healthful living environment for present and future Littleton

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
The lower building heights and larger step-backs along Bemis and Littleton Boulevard lessen
the visual impact on the adjoining neighborhood. In addition, providing residential housing near the light rail
transit will encourage walking and another mode of travel reducing the use of motor vehicles. The recommended
conditions of approval include widening the sidewalk and street right-of-way for Bemis Street, installing a traffic
signal at Bemis and Littleton Blvd., widening the sidewalk on the Alamo Bridge to provide safer pedestrian access to
the transit and downtown, conveying an easement to construct a trail connecting to the public trail system, and
constructing a sustainable building. Refer to staff conditions #2, 7, 8, and 10.

i.b: NOW: The setbacks and stepbacks along Bemis have been increased from 20’ to 25’ for Floors 1 and 2, and
subsequently increased to 30’ for Floor 3 and 50’ for Floor 4. The setbacks and stepbacks along Littleton
Boulevard have been increased from 10’ to 15’ for Floors 1 and 2, from 15’ to 20’ for Floor 3, from 35’ to 40’ for
Floor 4. In addition, a fifth floor has been removed. The recommended staff conditions 2, 7, 8 and 10, as
described above have been incorporated into the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Housing Policy 11: Encourage known energy efficient construction techniques in all types of housing.

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
Condition #3 requires a LEED standard to be met.

i.b: NOW: This condition is noted under Development Conditions on Sheet 2 of the PD plan.

page.text: The City shall emphasize the use of the Planned Development (PD) technique for all new
development within the City and provide incentives for developers to use this technique.

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
Approval of a Planned Development Plan is included with the rezoning request to PD-R. The
PD process allows specific standards to be applied to a particular development in order to mitigate impacts to the
surrounding neighborhood and area. In addition to development standards noted on the proposed PD Plan,
Conditions 1 through 12 meets this policy.

page.text: Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street

i.b: NOW: The above statement still applies. Staff recommended conditions 1 through 12 have been noted and
incorporated in the revised PD plan.

page.text: New development in the interior of established neighborhoods, not adjacent to arterial streets,
should respect the existing densities and land uses of the neighborhoods in order that the character is preserved.

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan: The proposal along with implementing the conditions of approval will result in a residential
development that is lower in scale and building mass, which is more compatible with the surrounding neighborhood.
Refer to conditions 1, 4, and 11.

i.b: NOW: Lowering the building height, removing the fifth floor, reducing the density, and increasing setbacks
have further reduced the scale and building mass making it more compatible with the surrounding
neighborhood. Staff recommended conditions 1, 4 and 11 are included in the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Provide traffic controls on internal residential and collector streets to improve safety
and to maintain proper levels of traffic speed and volume.

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan: The Littleton Boulevard Design Guidelines recommend properties on Littleton Boulevard
utilize the intersecting secondary streets, like Bemis Street, for access. The applicant proposes a traffic signal at
the intersection of Bemis and Littleton, and a “No Right Turn” sign on their site to prevent vehicles exiting the
development from traveling south into the neighborhood on Bemis Street. The applicant is agreeable to placing
other measures in the lease agreement (condition #6).

i.b: NOW: The applicant’s commitment to bearing the costs of the traffic signal and recommended condition #6 are
both noted on Sheet 2 of the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Transportation Policy 10: Maintain and improve existing sidewalks and bike systems so that safe access is

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
: Conditions 8 and 10 require widening of Bemis Street along the site’s frontage and
expanding the width of the sidewalk along the bridge over the railroad depression at Alamo to accommodate
increased pedestrian use.

i.b: NOW: Conditions 8 and 10 are included in the revised PD Plan both graphically and noted on Sheet 2.

page.text: Policy LU-10: Development adjacent to the identified iconic structures should respect and not detract from
their prominence. (Staff note: The plan identifies the Courthouse as such a structure)
LU-10a: Require that the height, scale, building placement, and other design elements of new construction,
expansion, or other property changes respect and do not overwhelm iconic structures. Employ techniques such
as building setbacks and step-backs for upper stories, and further detail that direction in the Downtown Design
Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street
Policy LU-12: Development in areas that are outside of downtown but immediately adjacent to downtown
gateways should be planned with consideration of their proximity to downtown and their potential role and
impact on downtown. The four gateways are located at Main Street/Littleton Boulevard, Main Street/Alamo
Street/Santa Fe Drive, Prince Street/Santa Fe Drive, and the Downtown Littleton light rail station.
LU-12a: Plan new developments immediately adjacent to downtown gateways so that they improve
connections to downtown, function as part of a gateway to downtown, follow the same design standards, and
are consistent with the Downtown Neighborhood Plan.

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
: Instead of one large building, the PD Plan proposes two separate buildings thereby
visually reducing the mass and scale of the project. The standards on the PD Plan and the recommended
conditions of approval provide building step-backs, which further reduce the scale of the building in relation to
the Historic Courthouse. Staff is also recommending a more robust architectural review process because of the
significance of the site (condition #4).

i.b: NOW: All graphics and notes on the PD Plan have been updated to show the new building design with
more traditional architecture consistent with the courthouse design. The new design is one level shorter and
steps farther back from Littleton Boulevard, which further reduces the scale of the building in relation to the
Historic Courthouse. Condition #4 is noted under the Development Conditions on Sheet 2.

page.text: Neighborhood Goal 1: Preserve the unique character of the neighborhood and general “quality of life” aspects,
especially the mix of architectural styles, mature trees, and quiet atmosphere of the residential areas.

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
The proposal along with implementing the conditions of approval will result in a residential
development that is lower in scale and building much more compatible with the surrounding neighborhood.
Implementing additional measures to reduce southbound traffic into the neighborhood is detailed in the
recommended conditions of approval. Staff is also recommending increasing the setback of the building on Bemis
Street (condition #1).

i.b: NOW: Lowering the building height, removing the fifth floor, reducing the density, and increasing setbacks
have further reduced the scale and building mass making it more compatible with the surrounding
neighborhood. The PD Plan now reflects the recommended increased building setback on Bemis Street. The
measures to reduce southbound traffic into the neighborhood are noted on Sheet 2 of the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Neighborhood Goal 2: Improve transportation facilities and traffic controls only to the extent necessary to
improve safety and to provide good traffic circulation within the neighborhood.
Transportation Policy 1: That traffic controls in internal residential and collector streets be maintained or
improved to improve safety and to prevent further increases in speed and volume of traffic.
Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
: The developer has committed to installing a traffic signal at Bemis and Littleton Blvd.
(condition #7).
Implementing additional measures to reduce southbound traffic into the neighborhood is described
in condition #6.

i.b: NOW: The developer’s commitment to both the traffic signal and measures to reduce southbound traffic on
Bemis (conditions 6 and 7) are noted on Sheet 2 of the revised PD Plan. The reduction in the number of
units will result in a reduction in the number vehicle trips generated.

page.text: That emphasis in the decision-making process be placed on the preservation of the
neighborhood as a sound, desirable residential area.

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
The design guidelines of the Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study recommend residential
development at a density of 50 units per acre. The proposal along with implementing the conditions of approval will
result in a residential development that is lower in scale and building mass, and is more compatible with the
surrounding neighborhood. Constructing two smaller building masses instead of one large building mass; providing
additional step-backs for floors above the second and third stories, design requirements, which further visually
break up the massing and lower the building near the courthouse meets the intent of the Littleton Boulevard
Corridor Study (condition #11). Emphasis in the decision-making process to preserve the neighborhood will be
accomplished with the recommended condition #4.

i.b: NOW: The revised proposal reduces the density to 50 du/ac. The conditions of approval, including the
referenced conditions #4 and #11 are incorporated into the revised PD Plan. The reduction in building
height, removal of the fifth floor and increased setbacks and step backs has further reduced the scale and
mass of the building making it more compatible with the surrounding neighborhood.

text.b: Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study Design Guidelines for Sheriff’s Site and Community

page.text: • 1C1.2 Building form next to Littleton Blvd. and Bemis Street should be a maximum of three stories,
stepping up in height away from the street.

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
: The setbacks along both Littleton Blvd. and Bemis Street are consistent with the above
guideline. The 1
st
and 2
nd
floors will be 10 feet from Littleton Blvd., 3rd floor will be 15 feet, and the 4th floor
will be 35 feet. The PD Plan proposes a 20 feet setback from Bemis for the 1
st
and 2
nd
floors, 25 feet for the 3
rd
floor and 45 feet for the 4
th
floor. Staff recommends that the 20 feet setback be increased to 25 feet adding five
feet more to the two upper setbacks to make this frontage more compatible with the east side of Bemis
(condition #1).

i.b: NOW: The setbacks and stepbacks along both Littleton Blvd. and Bemis Street have been increased. The
Bemis Street setback has been increased to 25’ for Floors 1 and 2, 30’ for Floor 3, and 50’ for Floor 4.
Littleton Blvd. setbacks are now 15’ for Floors 1-2, 20’ for Floor 3 and 40’ for Floor 4. The fifth floor has
been removed.

page.text: Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street
Goal 1: The architectural character should complement the existing historic architecture of this subarea.
Goal 2: To create buildings that provides human scale, interest, and variation.
• 1C3.1 All buildings should be designed especially for the context and character of the area.
• 1C3.2 The buildings should possess an architectural character that reinforces the historic character of the

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
: The greater setbacks and reduced building heights along Littleton Blvd. and Bemis Street
bring this building to a human scale with interest and variation. The larger step-backs above the second story
along Bemis Street make the building mass more compatible with the lower scale buildings along Bemis Street
and reinforce the prominence of the Courthouse. Refer to new conditions 1, 4, and 11.

i.b: NOW: As described previously, the proposed changes will result in a development consistent with the stated
goals. Staff recommended conditions 1, 4, and 11 are incorporated in the revised PD Plan.

page.text: • 1C6.1 Sloped roofs are preferred over flat roofs.

text.i: While the primary roof form will be flat, the development guidelines on the PD Plan state that some sloping
roof forms may be used to create visual interest and to relate to the adjacent buildings.

page.text: • 2A1 Building Relationships Goal: To present an attractive west façade to the light rail station and

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
: With the walkout basement level, the west side of the building will be six stories for the
majority of the elevation. However, the two separate buildings break up the visual massing along with
additional step backs and design requirements to create at least five-sub masses. Recommended condition #11
will further modify the setback standards for both the west and south elevations so 33% of the Level 5 of the
southern building shall step back 25 feet from the setback of the Level 1. In addition, recommended condition
#4 employs a process, which will include affected residents and the Planning Board during the finalization of
the architectural design.

i.b: NOW:
The lower building height, the greater setback from Littleton Boulevard, the screening of the walkout
basement level with a berm and the additional step backs and design requirements now give an appearance of
several three and four-story buildings along the western edge as shown on Sheet 3 of the PD plan. The
additional setback from Littleton Boulevard combined with the lower building height further reduces the scale
of the northerly portion of the building in relation to the Historic Courthouse. Staff’s recommended conditions
#4 and #11 as stated above have been added to the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street
Goals: To reflect the scale and height of the adjacent neighborhood and historic courthouse.
To maintain a two to three story edge to Littleton Blvd, particularly along the south side to
provide more sun exposure to the street.
• 2C1.1: Higher building forms should be located at the southwest and west portions of the site stepping
down toward Littleton Boulevard and Bemis Street. No building shall exceed the height of the
courthouse, 81 feet. (Staff note: The cupola is 81 feet while the larger mass of the building is shorter).
• 2C1.2: The building (s) along Bemis Street should respect the scale and pattern of the houses across the
street through such design strategies as the articulation of building form, column/pier spacing, window

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
: The plan proposes two separate structures similar to the above site plan. Additionally,
floor step backs above the second floor for the third and fourth stories along Bemis and Littleton Blvd. respect
the scale of the houses along Bemis and the prominence of the Courthouse. The taller portions of the buildings
will be concentrated at the southwest corner of the development.

page.text: Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street

text.i: As stated previously, recommended conditions of approval will further modify the setback standards for both
the west and south elevations and employ a process, which will include affected residents and the Planning
Board during the finalization of the architectural design (conditions 4 and 11).

i.b: NOW: As described previously, the proposed changes with greater setbacks and lower building heights will
result in a development consistent with the stated goals. Staff recommended conditions 4 and 11 are
incorporated in the revised PD Plan.

text.i: June 24/July 30 plan
The folded map included in the corridor study refers to medium density residential
development as up to 50 units per acre. The proposed density of 56 units per acre may be justified with the
recommended conditions, which include the developer providing trail connections, constructing a sustainable
building and providing safety improvements such as widening the Alamo bridge sidewalk and a traffic signal at
Bemis (conditions 2, 3, 7, and 10).

i.b: NOW: The proposed density has been reduced to 50 units per acre. Staff recommended conditions 2, 3, 7 and 10
are now incorporated in the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Section 10-2-23 (E) (4) (a) states that City Council base its decision on the conformance of the proposed plan
with the stated intent of the Planned Development District. Following are the pertinent citations:
10-2-23 (A): Intent: The Planned Development (PD) District is hereby created to promote the public health,
safety, and general welfare by allowing more flexible development, based upon a comprehensive, integrated
Application and Intent: Further, in the application of this Section it is the intent of the Council to:
1. Encourage more creative and effective use of land and public or private services, and to accommodate
changes in land development technology so that the resulting economies benefit the community.
• The additional residences at this location will increase the market for Main Street and Littleton

text.i: Boulevard businesses and note #3 under Development Conditions on Sheet 2 of the revised PD
Plan provides the opportunity for a limited residential use.

page.text: 2. Encourage innovation and efficiency in residential development to meet the growing demands for
housing of all types and designs for persons of any social or economic status.
• With a 4% apartment vacancy rate in Littleton, the development will meet the demand for

text.i: apartment housing and provide new product to an existing older housing stock. New energy
efficient building materials and appliances will help conserve natural resources.

page.text: Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street
3. Encourage innovative development or redevelopment of all land uses to meet the contemporary needs
of the community by providing for a greater variety and mix of uses including those which may coexist
on the same parcel or within the same building as shown on an approved general PD plan.
• As stated above, the development will provide new housing near downtown Littleton and the

text.i: light rail.

page.text: 4. Provide a process, which relates the design and development of a site to the particular
• The planned development plan process allows specific standards to be applied to a particular

text.i: development in order to mitigate impacts to the surrounding neighborhood and provide
additional offsite improvements to benefit the community. The recommended conditions of
approval agreed to by the applicant have been incorporated into the revised PD plan. This will
assure that the project will meet the intent of this statement. The project has been evaluated
against and is found to meet the Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study Design Guidelines for the
Sheriff’s site, which were created and adopted by Council to address the design and development
of the subject site.

page.text: 5. Require that the nature and intensity of development be supported by adequate utilities,
network, drainage systems, and open space to serve the development, and to minimize impacts on adjacent
• The development will link to a trail network, is adjacent to transit, and provides on-site

text.i: recreation facilities designed for the expected population. Existing utilities and roadways will
serve the site. In addition, further safety improvements will be provided such as a traffic signal
at Bemis Street and widening the sidewalk on the Alamo bridge.

page.text: 6. Encourage development that is consistent with the policies and guidelines established in the
adopted Comprehensive Plan for the area and for the City.
• As previously described, the proposed density, the larger step-backs above the second and third

text.i: stories and constructing two smaller building masses instead of one large structure, along with
the recommended conditions, are consistent with the intent of the COMPLAN and the Littleton
Boulevard Corridor Study.

page.text: Included in the attached application materials, the applicant has provided a fiscal benefit comparison showing
greater annual revenues and one-time fee and taxes for the proposed residential development versus a mixed use
allowed under the present B-2 zoning.
City Council recently adopted Ordinance No. 14, Series 2013, which requires payment of impact fees. If approved,
the developer will be required to pay an impact fee of $3,762 per unit at the time of building permit issuance.
Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street
Staff recommends approval of the proposed project as it is consistent with the Comprehensive Plan. The design,
height, form and density of the project, as bound by the Broadstone at Littleton Station general plan development
plan, is consistent with the goals, objectives and design guidelines of the Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study. In
addition, the project meets the intent of the Planned Development district.
On August 26, 2013, the Planning Board reviewed the revised rezoning request and modified general planned
development plan and voted 6-1 to deny Planning Board Resolution 13-07, which recommended approval. The
Board then voted 6-1 to approve Planning Board Resolution 13-08 that forwards a recommendation of denial to
City Council. Planning Board Resolution No. 13-08 and the draft minutes from the meeting are attached.
The attached ordinance, which was approved at first reading, has been amended due to the recent changes
proposed by the applicant at the Council meeting on July 30. Exhibit B, which listed the recommended
conditions of approval, has been removed because the revised PD Plan, dated August 21, 2013, contains the
• Approve the request with conditions reasonably related to meeting the criteria upon which the
granting of the application would be based;
• Approve a higher classification than requested;
• Or table the matter, to a date certain, pending the provision of further information by the
I move that the ordinance approving the rezoning of property known as 2100 W. Littleton Boulevard and 5759 S.
Bemis Street from B-2 Community Business District and R-3 Single Family Residential District, respectively, to
PD-R Planned Development Residential be approved as revised August 21, 2013.
Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R at 2100
W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street
Table 1: Changes made to PD Plan
Broadstone at Littleton Station Planned Development Plan, rev.08/21/13

text.b: STAFF REPORT SUPPLEMENT: QUESTIONS SUBMITTED FROM COUNCIL

page.text: 1. In terms of impact on the neighborhood (the architectural character, density, etc.), how does
the impact of the proposed rezoning/project compare -- not to the previous proposal that was
withdrawn last month and which I never studied or even read -- but instead to:
a. What already exists on the site?
b. What could be built with the current zoning for the site?

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: In the attached table (Broadstone at Littleton Station Development
Options) staff has attempted to compare what is existing on the site, what is proposed and
what the current B-2 zoning allows. This is similar to what the applicant provided within
their submittal. Please keep in mind that redevelopment of the site under the B-2 standards
may take many forms as there is not a height limit and a generous allowable building square
footage. Also, the allowed uses under B-2 include retail, office and residential (see
for a complete list of
allowable uses), with the requirement that no more than 50% of the square footage may be
residential. The numbers for the existing zoning represents development of a mixed-use
project at the maximum intensity allowed with 50% multi-family, retail on the first floor and
the remainder of the space as office.

page.text: 2. When I skimmed what was submitted to Council for the First Reading, I noted some of the
ways that the proposal will try to limit traffic impacts (e.g., if I recall correctly, occupants will
not be able to drive south when exiting the site will (or at least there will be a sign telling
them not to). But how will the proposal
a. constrain occupants and their visitors from approaching Broadstone by driving north or
south on Bemis, not using the parking lot and, instead, usurping the residential parking spaces
(and on-street parking for Sterne Park and the Rose Garden) on Bemis as far south as
Shepperd or even the short block further to Lake? (During Fall and Spring semesters, many
Auraria students park there; and many people who ride the Light Rail park there all year
b. constrain occupants and their visitors from driving north through the Sterne Park
Neighborhood; for example, driving from Sterne Parkway, driving east or west on Lake
(connecting to Windermere or to S Prince to head north or south on Prince to avoid downtown
red lights and congestion), and south on Spotswood, to connect to Lake, Caley Ave, Ridge
Rd, etc. to head to Broadway or S Santa Fe)?

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: There is nothing to keep residents or visitors to Broadstone from parking
on Bemis from Littleton Boulevard to Lake Street. However, the first spaces used will be
those that are closest to their destination which will be on-site. The project is providing the
code required number of parking spaces. Future occupants and residents certainly could
travel the public streets you have mentioned. The applicant is proposing measures to make
entering the site from the north, or exiting to the south difficult with the alignment of the
driveway and taking management steps to reduce the likelihood.

page.text: 3. How many residents will, realistically, drive to work (rather than take the Light Rail)? How
many of cars will be able to exit via the traffic light onto Littleton Blvd during each cycle of
the light during rush hour? (Note: During morning rush hour, they will probably not be able
to make a right turn without a green light, because of the heavy traffic flow.) How many cars
will be able to queue up on Bemis between that traffic light and the exit from the parking lot?

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: It is estimated that there will be a 10% reduction in vehicle trips due to
proximity to the light rail station. So, of those who must travel to work, 90% are expected to
drive. The actual timing of the traffic light has not been determined at this time. It is 410 feet
between the entrance to the project and Littleton Boulevard. Assuming the left turn lane is a
minimum of 200 feet, this allows 610 feet of queuing, or approximately 30 vehicles.

page.text: 4. The proposed height of the building does not exceed the Court House (and thus complies
with, I believe, the Littleton Corridor Plan). But how does the plan address
a. the issue of scale/mass, compared to the Court House and the houses across the street
on the east side of Bemis and in the nearby neighborhood, particularly between Shepperd and
Lake, between Sycamore and S Spotswood?
b. the historic character of the immediate neighborhood, including, for example,
3) many other historic houses on both sides of Littleton Blvd, 2 or 3 blocks east, whose
live-in owners have been investing so much money in to upgrade, while preserving the
4) other historic houses in the Sterne Park Neighborhood, especially those between
Shepperd and Lake (some of which have been recently upgraded with an effort to preserve
c. the historic Downtown area, including
1) the Main Street Historic District itself
2) buildings that could be admitted to the Main Street Historic District but have not
3) the historic character of many buildings that are not part of that district (on Alamo
and many of the N/S and E/W streets north of Main Street and several that are between Alamo

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: The staff report includes the goals of the Comprehensive Plan,
Downtown Neighborhood Plan and the Littleton Corridor Study, the majority of which state
the importance of the Courthouse and existing neighborhoods. The requested zoning gives
the Council an opportunity to weigh each of these goals, policies and criteria of these
documents against the proposal to change the use of the site; whereas development of the site
under the existing zoning does not.

page.text: 5. What is the anticipated impact on use of Sterne Park, the Rose Garden and the Buck

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: The applicant is projecting a population of 500 residents from the project.
It is difficult to estimate the impact this increase in population will have on these specific
facilities. However, the developer is required to pay a one-time impact fee for expansion of
all city facilities. In addition, the Buck Center offsets their operating costs with user fees.

page.text: Can we get a fairly current traffic count on Littleton Blvd just east of the railroad tracks? What
is the road capacity? and will the proposed development exceed the design capacity?

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: The City’s traffic counts for 2011 indicate between Prince and Broadway
that there is an average of 23,196 trips per day. The measure of design capacity is the rating
on the level of service (LOS) for an intersection (a=good and f=bad). Staff concurs with the
traffic report which states that with the proposed project and accompanying traffic light at
Bemis and Littleton Boulevard, this intersection will be at a LOS of B.

page.text: If people are concerned about traffic going south from Broadstone, can we close Bemis street

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: This may warrant further consideration. It would allow free pedestrian
movement between Sterne Park and the retention basin south of the proposed project. One
concern would be providing an additional access to the residents on Bemis Street in case an
incident, such as a traffic accident, closes access to Littleton Boulevard temporarily.

page.text: Can you give more details about what could be built under the current zoning -- all the types of
commercial, number of residential units, height of bldg allowed, parking requirements and can
the site accommodate the parking under the maximum development, required open space for
current, anything else you can provide. Sometimes what is available under permitted is worse
than what is proposed, and I want to understand these differences.

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: Please refer to the attached table “Broadstone at Littleton Station
Development Options”. As stated above, the configuration of the redevelopment of the site
under the existing B-2 zoning is limited by the requirements that the gross floor area of
buildings cannot exceed twice the area of the parcel (392,040 square feet); 20% must be open
space; setbacks and parking have to be provided. The other variables that will affect the form
of the development will be the market and the costs of construction.

page.text: The following is on the Ordinance, Exhibit B:
#1: if this was 20 feet, which I think is common in other places; could the buildings fit better on

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: Reducing the setback on Bemis Street would provide more buildable area
on the site. Staff is recommending the additional setback to match the average of the setback
that exists on the east side of Bemis Street and match what would be required under the B-2
zoning.

page.text: #4: be prepared for the public hearing to explain why this is a requirement for this development
when it has not been for others.

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: The developer suggested an increased level of architectural review. Staff
agrees that the context of this site is unique and therefore the additional effort is warranted.

page.text: #4.d: did the developer request a public gathering place, or is that staff's requirement, and why?
#5: is the retail a desire of the developer or the staff? If this space is apartments, could the 6th

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: This is something the developer is incorporating into their Cherry Hills
project and would like the opportunity for this in Littleton. Staff made it a part of the PD
because we think it could be an amenity for the neighborhood, would generate some revenue
for the city, but not be of a scale that competes with businesses in downtown or along Littleton
Boulevard. The space is only 1,200 square feet, so if it is not a “retail café or similar
neighborhood scale retail” it would be an apartment unit.
STAFF RESPONSE: Our enforcement responsibility will be only to ensure that there is
language in the lease agreement penalizing residents who exit to the south or enter from the
south.

page.text: #7: will the developer know what will be required prior to permit, or will it come as a surprise?

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: The building permit review will include the design of the intersection and
traffic signal that are prepared by the developer and approved by the Public Works
Department. They are aware of the costs involved. The developer will be required to install
these improvements prior to approving the certificate of occupancy for any unit.

page.text: #8: widen only at the property limits of this development and not further south?

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: Yes, though some transition area may be required south of the site.

page.text: #9: I am somewhat bothered by this being a requirement
#10: this is a benefit to the "other" public as well; shouldn't the city contribute some to this cost?

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: Staff believes this is warranted as a developer expense because of the
increase in population that will be crossing the bridge to the light rail station.

page.text: #11: is this another reason why there are six floors when there could be five?

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: The requirement is not causing the addition of a sixth floor; it is an effort
to reduce the visual impact of the sixth floor by breaking it up into separate masses.

page.text: Is my reading correct that the Littleton Community Trail will be allowed along the west side of

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: Yes they are incorporating it into the emergency access that is required
along the west and south. Dedication of an easement for the trail is included in condition #2.

page.text: There is no legend to the document to note the significance of non-italicized versus italicized
comments/descriptions/positions/rationale. Please clarify who is stating, or what documents are
being referenced. Also, please distribute the referenced documents, so that comments/excerpts
• Design Guidelines for the Sheriff’s Department Site (2000 West Littleton Boulevard)
Are the ‘Citywide Goals’ referenced, those from the Council’s Goals and Objectives? If not, please

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: The Citywide Goals are from the Comprehensive Plan, not Council’s
Goals and Objectives. Here are the links to the referenced documents:
Citywide Goals and Sterne Park Neighborhood Plan contained in the current comprehensive
plan found here
There is discussion about gateways to the downtown (which this is) located in the Downtown
Neighborhood Plan
The Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study; Design Guidelines for The Sheriff’s Department Site
(subject site) and Community Center Site. Pay particular attention to the text on the map at the
end of the document

page.text: The Planning Board minutes/discussion were not included with the Agenda Communication of
02JUL2013. Please include/distribute those, and reference the meeting date at which the public
hearing, discussion, and consideration were made.

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: Done.

page.text: Section 10-2-23 has requirements for a PD-R re-zone, that there be 25+% of unobstructed open

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: In the table on the cover page of the PD-R is their commitment to
providing a minimum of 30% unobstructed open space.

page.text: There does not seem to be any response from the applicant to the ‘staff’ proposed conditions 1-
12. Where in the package are the applicant’s changes to accommodate / respond / include these
modifications? I am not following what the applicant is proposing, what modifications have been
made, and what modifications the applicant is choosing to have the Council evaluate in lieu of
addressing the Staff’s conditions. If the Staff’s conditions are addressed, would the Planning

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: The applicant stated at the June 24 Planning Board meeting that they

page.text: agreed to the conditions presented by staff. The physical changes to the project and adjacent

text.i: right-of-way recommended in the conditions have to be approved by staff before a building
permit would be issued. The Board was aware the developer agreed to the conditions, but did
not see the physical changes to the structure caused by the implementation of #1, 5 and 11.

page.text: I recall from some prior discussions that part of a re-zoning requirement is that there has been
some ‘change in conditions.’ Please elaborate upon these criteria, and its applicability to this
application. [There has been some comments made that the property could be built out with the
current zoning, and that mass would be greater than the varied/modified applications. If so, why

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: Section 10-12-1 of the Littleton Zoning Code requires that for the zoning to
be changed it has to be consistent with the goals and policies of the comprehensive plan and it
promotes the general welfare of the community. Absent that, the applicant must demonstrate the
rezoning is justified because of “…changed or changing conditions in the particular area or city
in general…” It is staff’s contention the request is consistent with the goals of the
comprehensive plan as described in the staff report. Attached to this supplement is a
spreadsheet that illustrates what could be built under the existing B-2 zoning. The rezoning is
necessary for the total floor area to be devoted to greater than 50% residential use.

page.text: How will this application produce something that is ‘complementary’ to the Sterne Park

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: It is staff’s recommendation that the proposed project, with the additional
12 modifications and conditions, meets the goals and policies of the comprehensive plan and the
design guidelines of the Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study. However, redevelopment of the site
under the current B-2 zoning, which requires no public review or approval, would be contrary to
the Sterne Park Neighborhood Plan which states: “Prohibit encroachment of commercial uses
into established residential areas by limiting such uses to existing commercial districts such as
Littleton Boulevard”.

page.text: VII. The documents are difficult to follow electronically. Can a document package be produced and
distributed that clearly delineates the different sections, the purposes of the sections, etc.?

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: Hopefully we have done that.

page.text: VIII. We had discussed having better ‘visuals’ for what the build out might look like would be
beneficial. Where are such visuals for this application? Can what is proposed in the rezoning
application and the alternative as with the Staff conditions be included? Can the surrounding
properties/environment be shown for comparisons, context, etc.? These would be helpful to
determine if there will be something complementary.

text.i: STAFF RESPONSE: The applicant will present a computer generated model of the project and
how it will appear in the actual context and topography of the site. It will allow them to show
views from any perspective. Attached to this supplement are more detailed building elevations
that were part of the June 24 Planning Board presentation.

page.text: The Littleton City Planning Board met on Monday, August 26, 2013, in the Council Chambers of
the Littleton City Center, 2255 West Berry Avenue. The meeting convened at 7:00 p.m.
Board Member Rudnicki moved that planning board approve the July 22, 2013, minutes,
Ben Burkett, 5730 S. Bemis St., wanted to thank the volunteer board members for their time.
Acknowledged that the board has asked that there not be duplicate or repetitive comments from
people, but states it is their right to speak even if it is repeated.
Pam Chadbourne, 5402 S. Nevada St. She presented information about radicalism in the city
of Littleton in regards to rezoning high-density apartment housing. She stated the citizens need
to know the reasons, advantages, disadvantages, risks, and benefits for current zoning and what
will happen to the city over time. She commented on impacts, investments and traffic.
Sharleen Williams, 850 West Powers Drive, stated she has come to talk about the density of in
District 2. She expressed concerns relating to the impacts the new apartment developments will
have on the school system, aging apartment buildings and crime.
Colleen Gray, 3080 W. Prentice Ave., Littleton stated she bought a condo at Steeplechase, and
expressed concerns regarding the proposed rezoning of the Villages of Belleview because it
affects traffic, quality of life, and property values. Concerned about high-density housing
Chair Duzan asked if there was anyone else interested in speaking. No one else came forward.

text.b: Rezoning from B2 and R3 to PD-R, 2100 Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis St..

page.text: Chair Duzan stated this was brought forward a month ago and recommended to the council and
council chose to remand it back to the board because of changes to application. The board wants
to focus on the changes that relate to change in density, height, and setbacks. Board has already
heard testimony on the other issues, so they want to keep this focused on these changes. Invited
Jan to present city’s staff report.
Jan Dickinson, Principal Planner, opened the presentation. Ms. Dickinson presented the List of
Exhibits, which included letters that city staff received from citizens today. Summarized
changes from the applicant from June 24 PD plan. Reduction of units from 250 to 225, density
from 56 to 50 units per acre, max height from 59 feet to 49 feet, stories from 5 to 4 stories,
building set back on Littleton Blvd from 10 to 15 feet. Other changes are the conditions of
approval previously recommended by staff. The applicant has agreed to these conditions and
transferred them all on to the PD plan document.
Chair Duzan asked if she could explain a “split signal” traffic signal proposed at Bemis and
Jan Dickinson gave examples of an existing split signal on Bowles.
Board Member Graham explained a split signal is when you turn and go into a “holding tank”
of 1, 2, or 3 spaces where there is a second light that releases you into the traffic flow.
Chair Duzan stated that they will have the applicant explain it more at their time.
Glen VanNimwegen, Community Development Director, talked in detail about the plan
development and comprehensive plan that is outlined in full in the Staff Report. Specifically,
discussed areas in which the project will be maintaining the character and expectations of the
City of Littleton residential living. As examples, explained the widening of Bemis street and
providing pedestrian crossings. He explained the additional development conditions such as
sound and construction measures, and building setbacks, which can be reviewed on the plan.
Staff recommends approval of the modifications.
Chair Duzan asked if there were any questions of the Board had staff can address at this point.
Board Member Rudnicki quoted Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study under recommended
market about density of 50 units per acre being supportable. He stated the study did not mention
that density west of Windemere. Stated that density can vary depending on where you are, so
cannot put a blanket density of 50 units per acre on Littleton Boulevard. Asked why the study
was not included in the COMPLAN.
Glen VanNimwegen explained that council believed it was too detailed to be part of the
Comprehensive Plan. Planned development plan is a process used to create better design for a
project. This is the process to implement the design guidelines and make them part of an
ordinance with regard to the effective law.
Chair Duzan asked if there were any other questions for staff before moving to the applicant.
None asked. Invited the applicant to present application.

text.b: Andy Clay, Alliance Residential Company, 2000 S. Colorado Blvd., Ste. 10500 in Denver,

page.text: CO. He explained that residents approached them after last meeting and asked for some
changes that would make this development worthwhile. Worked through that with them, and
believes they are supporting the project now. Provided summary of application, evolution of
design, justification for rezoning, consistency with city goals and policies, and fiscal benefits
analysis. Proposed PD-R will have the least impact on the neighborhood, generate less trips per
day and require less parking spaces. Discussed how this project will raise the standard for luxury
multifamily residential living. Discussed compliance with ordinances and adopted plan.
Introduced their consulting economic analyst to explain fiscal benefits and changes.
Dan Guimond with Economic and Planning Systems gave background of company and his
part in this particular project. Measured fiscal revenues for Alliance on this project and
compared it to an alternative scenario under different zoning. Revenue summary reviewed for
this project initially compared to proposed. Reviewed demographics with regards to rent rates
between current and proposed zoning. Looked at demographics in number of new projects in the
city and demographics for this project are above levels that they originally calculated at over
$50,000 for single person and $100,000 for couples and roommates. Reviewed calculations of
retail spending and sales tax between two zoning options. Compared spending to surrounding
areas and state that roughly half of the expenditures would be spent in Littleton. Reviewed
property taxes for residential properties. Reviewed impact fees and permits. Other benefits of
proposed zoning reviewed. Stated there are stronger transit benefits with proposed zoning.

text.b: Mackenzie Jellum , Alliance Residential Company,2000 S. Colorado Blvd., Ste. 10500,

page.text: Denver, CO, 80222, shared photos of another property they developed near Alameda and
Colorado (Broadstone Gardens at Cherry Creek) to show what to expect in this current project,
as they are similar. Focused on Wi-Fi café, fitness center, and amenities of the property in
Cherry Creek. This project has 191 units. She then presented Max Scott, consultant who
Max Scott, Oedipus, Inc. reviewed history of his business, which performs opinion polls and
surveys. He provided copies of the survey report to the Board. He was retained by Alliance to
do a survey for existing zoning versus the proposed zoning. He presented a diagram defining the
neighborhood that was polled. Explained the results obtained, showing the number of residents
polled, for or against the project.
Andy Clay came forward to conclude their presentation and stated that Alliance has tried very
hard to respond to resident concerns.
Chair Duzan asked to restate unit sizes and mix.
Andy Clay stated an average unit size is 947 square feet and the unit mix of 41 percent 1
bedroom/1 bath and 59 percent 2 bedroom/2 bath.
Further discussion with the applicant and staff ensued regarding the density figures mentioned in
the Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study: 50 du/ac under the section “Recommendations Market”
Board Member Rudnicki stated that the applicant could have gone to lower number versus the
Chair Duzan opened the hearing for public comment.
Paul Bingham, 236 West Delaware Circle, submitted a letter to the Board. Stated that he is
opposed to the project. Stated concerns of building height and mass, inconsistent with
Marty Bolt, 6187 S. Windemere Way, Opposed to the project. Stated concerns regarding traffic
Carol Brzeczek in District 4 at 2000 W Arapaho Road stated that she is opposed to this project.
Stated concerns about the building height, it is not a four-story building, taking away from the
historic courthouse and destroying the character of the neighborhood.
Lou Sullivan, 5940 S. Bemis Street, opposed to project. Concerns about building height and size,
dwarfing the courthouse and not in character with the neighborhood.
Erin Aldrich, 5731 S. Spotswood Street, stated she’s been a Littleton resident for over 30 years
and is against the rezoning and the building of this massive project on this site.
Nancy Barger at 6149 S Bemis Street opposed to the project. Concerned about traffic and
construction in the surrounding areas. Follow the wishes of the citizens and keep the character
Sharleen Williams at 850 West Powers Drive, opposed to project and the high-density. This
building will destroy District 2 as it will use all our resources.
Jeanie Erickson at 5567 South King Street stated there have been four high density apartment
complexes approved already and approving this one will not match the historical architecture of
the area. Stated she believes enough has been added and plan looks like a box. Does not care
about how long the roof will last, but cares about long-term effect and recommends project be
Colleen Grey at 3080 West Prentice Avenue, opposed to project. Questioned the sales taxes and
where the money will be spent. Appalled at the size of the building. Does not believe it is
compatible with history and quality of Littleton.
Betty Harris at 6281 South Cedar Street, opposed to project stated she was interested in survey
with the map because in that area she got 135 signatures in a petition against rezoning.
Concerned about the density, too many apartments in Littleton, crowding, distress and crime.
Ben Burkett at 5730 South Bemus Street stated he lives across the street from the proposed
development in a historic home, opposed to project. This project does not fit into the historic
characteristic of the neighborhood. Concerned about parking and traffic impacts. Most other
Brenda O’Connell at 5791 South Spotswood Street stated she is against the rezoning of massive
high density apartment complex because it is not the right place. It will forever change the area
and degrade the character of the area. It will not preserve the unique aspects of the
neighborhood. Stated there are too many traffic and parking concerns as well.
Leah Burkett at 5730 South Bemis Street stated the project tonight looks like the same project
presented two months previously. Stated widening the bridge on Alamo puts pedestrians and
cars too close together. Showed video of commute on Alamo bridge to show being closer to the
cars would be frightening. There are already enough high density apartments. There are other
options to build, such as a lower density complex.
Mike Geraty at 5675 South Crocker Street stated survey results may be skewed based on what
residents want to see on that piece of land. Would not have bought home if knew about the
project. Already approved several rental projects, no reason to add more. Too many floors on
building, so asked to say no to the project.
Gerard Halleren at 5551 South Cedar stated he is opposed. There is an absence of information.
Parking for 1-1/2 vehicles seems inadequate for the income bracket. Too many questions and
opacity with regard to traffic. Would like to see something with more transparency in building
Kathy Messenger at 5743 Shasta Circle stated she would like the board to cast a vote against
project because the project does not fit in with Littleton character. Too dangerous to widen the
sidewalk on the bridge, as the blind school is not too far away from that spot. Asked the board to
consider that. Stated project is not right for the city or community.
Joseph Devlin at 5870 South Bemis Street stated building this project is unbelievable. Most
concerning is the traffic on Bemis because road is already narrow. Residents of the new
apartment will go to Bemis to get out or get in and will cause dangerous traffic issues. Urged
board to vote no on the project.
Pam Chadbourne at 5402 South Nevada Street stated that the building is five stories because
basement is still a floor. There have been several revisions, which are appreciated, but still not
fit for this site. Added this building will lose Downtown discriminator. Project does not
completely comply with Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study.
Thomas Obrien at 5652 South Cedar Street is in favor of the project. He stated change and
progress is necessary. Would like to see more change in Littleton so asking to vote in favor of
Gary Johnson at 5753 South Prescott Street stated he is a traffic engineer who was originally
opposed but is now supportive because he would like to continue dialogue with developer and he
believes this is an appropriate use of the site. Discussed trip generation and that it is not
Francis Pierson at 1950 West Littleton Boulevard stated he had been consistently against
proposal until about a month ago, but is now in favor because worked with the developer to
make a proposal that is more appropriate for the needs of the community. Believes the developer
was considerate of the request, so believed there is a common ground that can be met.
Norm Brown in District 1 at 6081 South Spotswood discussed rail traffic. Advised against
putting any residential buildings on this property.
Christine DeOrio at 5652 South Spotswood Street stated bought home a couple of months ago
because liked the old town Littleton feel. Stated this project is simply not the right fit for the city
or area because would take away from the character of Littleton and transform the neighborhood
Andrew Benedik at 5905 South Crocker Street, Alliance worked directly with him and met with
them several times finding ways to make the project more acceptable, so now favors the project
because Alliance has been understanding and cooperative. This project is better than what could
possibly go there. Feels that 225 is an acceptable number of units.
Susan Burkstoner 6120 South Sterne Parkway stated the project does not adhere to goals of the
community. Stated developer’s numbers of economic benefits do not match the reality of the
downtown area. Project does not meet comp plan goals and policies, so opposed to the project.
Norman Stucker at 801 Shady Croft Lane and office is 2009 West Littleton Boulevard, the
courthouse office building. Stated that the buildings built later in 1960s did not take away from
the older buildings and does not believe the new buildings will either, but will enhance and add
to the architecture of the neighborhood. Believes it is consistent with local buildings because
there are four story buildings. Downside is traffic. Would appreciate a light at Bemis and
Littleton to get to Sterne Park.
Mary Weis at 1953 West Lily Ave stated that cannot walk on Alamo so will not walk down to
light rail any more. If going to increase amount of people, need a pedestrian bridge, not just a
widening of the sidewalk. Concerned with density because density in Littleton is already pretty
Stew Meagher at 6696 South Crocker Way suggested that developer is collaborative and since
something is going to happen on that site, should work with a developer that works with the
community. Needs to move the city forward, so asks board to support the project.
Doug Clark at 2454 Houstoun Waring stated surprise in that Littleton Corridor Study is just a
guideline. There have been renditions, but the building is still massive and garage will still need
to be five stories. That development would not be compatible with single-family historic area,
and is not compatible with the Littleton corridor study. Urges board to turn this project down.
The following citizens signed the public hearing roster, are opposed to the project but did not
wish to speak: Vicki Peterson, Roger Peterson, Susan Geraty, Joel Grossheusru, Lori Schultz,
John Schultz, Gaye Denley, Dale Hilborn, Richard Camp, Patrick Sullivan, Cora Devlin, Dan
Messer, Doug Krenik, Mike Gasper ,Ray Flesher, Virginia Camp, Olcott Pinkston, Peter
TenEyck, Dave Mitchell, Betty Carr, Sue Young, Solbritt Murphy,
Chair Duzan stated would like to give the applicant the opportunity to respond to the comments.
Andy Clay, stated he would like to disagree with definition of medium density as it’s been
described. Read portion about Development Catalyst Sites in corridor study. Proposed that 40
units/acre was a baseline minimum/threshold point. Changes have not been cosmetic. Changes
to height and density (per city code) setbacks are significant changes to the project and to the
number of units, parking, trips generated, and steps back on third and fourth floors. Company
has listened to the concerns of the citizens, but each reason to deny proposal are components that
would be an issue in the current use by right and probably significantly greater. I see this as a
proposal of limits. A project that limits current parking, trips per day, height, architecture,
design quality and construction quality in a way that B-2 zoning does not. Widening Alamo
does include a slush barrier built in addition to that widening to protect the walkway from slush
and rain, creating a better condition.
Asked why would someone rent at this rate when could buy? Answer is because of the bubble
that happened in single family residential. Tying up 20% equity is not necessarily best use of
capital. Doesn’t mean they’re not committed to community. Understands this is a wonderful
neighborhood, which is why so much corroboration has been done with citizens.
Board Member Kari Elrod, had a question for the city, has the Littleton Boulevard corridor
Jan Dickinson stated it was accepted by council, ratified.
Board Member Elrod asked Andy how many parking spaces.
Board Member Elrod asked if that includes visitors.
Andy Clay stated it does include visitor, and 1.5 is a minimum that is believed to be adequate for
Board Member Elrod asked about current zoning and whether still needs to abide by Corridor
Mr. Van Nimwegen stated that the design guidelines may be used for physical design, but can’t
limit current zoning by land use restrictions in design guidelines. Do that through zoning, not
Board Member Elrod asked if zoning would override the land use recommendations in the
Board Member Bolt asked about the PD plan. Termination element which is View 7, southeast
elevation, page 4. Basement story is visible above ground.
Mr. Clay stated software does not address topography, so he introduced his architect to answer.
Harsh Parikh, architect stated when trying to input topography into the program, portions
shown in picture are not there. This is due to the slope and a flaw in the program. There will be
no basement component to northerly half. He further stated the entire west side of the south
building and a portion of the south side of the southerly building will have the walkout basement.
Basement level will provide access to sidewalks for pedestrians.
Chair Duzan asked if the berm needs approval from City of Englewood and asked if there have
Harsh Parikh stated there have been some discussions, but not detailed. Englewood would
have some concerns about trees being planted in the city ditch easement.
Board Member Moore asked about parking. Currently enough for each bedroom to have one
car. Wants to know if extra vehicles would be on the street.
Andy Clay stated that is correct, currently at minimum of one space per bed. Stated they didn’t
think more parking than that would be necessary but will work with residents if they want that.
Chair Duzan, asked about signalization with left turn, about stacking, trying to make left turn on
Bemis if there are only two spaces on a busy day. Asked if there is a commitment/requirement
that stacking goes along with reconfiguring of the intersection?
Charles Buck, Felsburg, Holt, and Ullevig (Traffic Consultant) stated if signalized, What is
existing would be sufficient stacking. The lane is about 60 feet which would hold about two to
Board Member Baertlein asked Glen/city to confirm if plan for site redevelopment says four
Mr. VanNimwegen stated height is called out in design guidelines and also in Staff Report.
Chair Duzan stated at this point that he would like to close public hearing, thanked everyone for
comments. Open up to the board for deliberation, comments, thoughts.
Chair Duzan asked for a motion.
Board Member Samuelson moved to approve Planning Board Resolution 13-07, which
forwards a recommendation of approval to city council.
Board Member Elrod seconded the motion.
Chair Duzan stated there is a motion and second to approve Board Resolution 13-07.
Board Member Moore addressed inability to grow in Littleton. Majority of proposal is on
Bemis, not on Littleton. Neighborhood Goal Number 1 is not fit because project is a gateway
and need to preserve character of neighborhood.
Board Member Samuelson not opposed to multifamily housing in Littleton, it’s inevitable.
Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study is poorly written and conflicting in many areas. This project
does not meet Sterne Park neighborhood goals. Detracts from Sterne Park.
Board Member Elrod stated this is how it is supposed to work with plans and guidelines to
guide judgment with building projects. Decision difficult because it’s a great project but
important site in Littleton so there is a lot of scrutiny. Comp plan, corridor study, Sterne Park all
working in conjunction to help make the decision. Strong plan but feel need to use tools to guide
Board Member Graham stated that he is impressed with project presentation and steps taken to
reduce density. Commendable about not giving up. Design is very well done, and benefit if
keeps with style of historic Littleton. This site should be multi-family housing, but what was
presented was not enough. Appreciates that multi-family would help businesses prosper.
Timeless location in Littleton and believes developer takes this seriously, but still looking for
something different and more fitting and unique to the property. Vote will likely be no because
he doesn’t think the architectural design of the property would be unique enough for that spot.
Board Member Rudnicki discussed the quote about “following the mob.” He has been a
proponent of multi-family projects all throughout Littleton. Discussed the issue with the number
of stories and the confusion of it in regard to sloping, berms, and other ways around the story
limitations. Quoted more about the plan and how it does not meet limitations and guidelines.
Drawing on page 16 of corridor story reviewed. Tedious architecture and not unique. Stated
need to live with zoning given for the area.
Board Member Bolt brought up comment of token vote and that that is not true. Project looks
good. Stated he is not concerned with density but concerned about picture in corridor study the
sloping roofs but is more of an overhang. East elevation that faces single family houses does not
match the neighborhood. Is not what the community is looking for. Urged the developers to
keep trying for a project that fits the site
Alt. Board Member Baertlein stated that this is a big site and the project does not fit with the
development, but it is a great project and have done well with making changes. The use is not
necessarily contradictory to good planning principles.
Chair Duzan thanked developer for their persistence and cooperation with the citizens. There
are still things that need to be worked out but they are site plan items, not zoning items. The site
is a prime transit site and should be residential. Just in that regard, the architecture should be
more compatible with the surrounding neighborhood. Would like a building that fits the historic
community. Asks for any other follow-up comments.
Board Member Elrod stated this is an exciting piece of land that needs a great, unique idea.
Don’t have a lot of single family housing, so would like to see something great that will be there
for a long time to come and mean a lot to the city.

text.b: Motion failed 1-6 with Chair Duzan voting in favor.

page.text: Deputy City Attorney, Kristin Schledorn, stated that the city code requires the Planning Board
forward a resolution with recommendation to City Council so she asked for a 10-minute recess to
draft a resolution recommending denial based on discussion and bring back for consideration and
Principal Planner Jan Dickinson prepared different resolution 13-08 with planning board
recommending denial of the request and justification that rezoning is inconsistent with goals and
Chair Duzan asked if they need to vote?
Deputy City Attorney, Kristin Schledorn stated that the board can make a motion to approve
this resolution or make a different motion. But, they need a resolution before it can go to
Board Member Elrod offered a different motion to recommend approval Resolution 13-07
which will forward a recommendation of approval with conditions reducing the density to 43.45
units per acre, which is consistent with R-5 zoning.
Chair Duzan asked for a second. None given.
Board Member Elrod asked if they can do this and adopt Resolution of 13-07, in the packet,
with condition that density could not exceed 43.56 du/acre, roughly 196 units.
Deputy City Attorney, Kristin Schledorn, answered yes.
Board Member Moore asked about including the acreage with easements in the density
Chair Duzan stated that they need a second before debate. Board Member Graham seconded.
Chair Duzan explained that all acreage of the property is used in calculating the density.
Board Member Graham expressed concern about making decision at such a late hour. Would
like to offer suggestions to the project, but wants it to be well thought out.
Board Member Elrod explained reasoning for R-5 condition, because it is more compatible
Board Member Bolt stated that his issue isn’t with density but with visuals of the exterior on
Chair Duzan stated they can vote on this. Asked if there was any other discussion prior to vote.
Board Member Elrod asked if the vote does not work out, how they can continue this
Deputy City Attorney, Kristin Schledorn, stated they need to table decision of case if they
cannot pass a vote. The process will not be completed if a vote doesn’t go through. Applicant
needs to agree to later date if the Board tables its decision.
Chair Duzan called the vote on motion with the condition of density reduction.

text.b: The motion failed 1-6 with Board Member Elrod voting in favor.

page.text: Chair Duzan moved to table the decision to give the applicant time to work out densities and
Andy Clay stated that he does not have the authority to agree to the tabling.
Board Member Rudnicki made a motion that we approve resolution 13-08, which recommends
Board Member Bolt seconded the motion.

outline.item: Littleton Letter of Intent and Executive Summary 8 12 13
Declaration for Public Policy of Rezoning 8 12 13
